image.altText: A woman's hands resting in her lap. She's wearing rings, bracelets and a watch

items.synopsis: Prisha's elderly neighbour had heard the commotion coming from her Brisbane home for months and decided to take action. The small act of kindness changed the migrant's life.

title.children: Prisha didn't realise she was suffering from domestic violence. To her, it was 'normal'

image.altText: Tyre tracks on grass with Maryborough town sign in background

items.synopsis: A 13-year-old boy allegedly driving a stolen car has been charged over a horror crash that has killed three people in Maryborough, north of Brisbane.

title.children: Boy, 13, charged over triple-fatal crash involving allegedly stolen car

image.altText: A satellite image of a large black submarine on land surrounded by industrial buildings and cranes near the water.

items.synopsis: Until Australia's submarine fleet can go nuclear the navy must keep its near-retirement vessels deployable. It's been a struggle.

title.children: How Australia was left with only one deployable submarine

image.altText: A composite image of Marion Scrymgour, Lidia Thorpe and Jacinta Nampijinpa Price

items.synopsis: The 2022 federal election delivered record results for First NationsÂ representation in parliament. Ahead of the referendum, the ABC contacted the 11 politicians to hear directly from them what they think about a constitutionally enshrined Voice to Parliament.

title.children: There are 11 First Nations MPs and senators. Here's what they think of a Voice to Parliament

image.altText: An AFL executive speaks at a lectern.

items.synopsis: The AFL is set to name Andrew Dillon its next chief executive, taking over from Gillon McLachlan, who announced his upcoming resignation almost a year ago.

title.children: AFL names next chief executive almost a year after Gillon McLachlan's resignation

schema.headline: Andrew Dillon named AFL chief executive almost a year after Gillon McLachlan's resignation

liveBlogUpdate.headline: That's all from Andrew Dillon and Richard Goyder
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The AFL Commission chairman and AFL CEO-elect shake hands and bring the press conference to an end. Thanks for joining for the live portion, we'll have plenty more news and reaction to Dillon's appointment throughout the day at abc.net.au/sport .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'A truly national game': Dillon's pitch for the future
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "It's about being truly national. We have a truly national competition we want to be a truly national sport overseen by a truly national organisation. "We want to see AFL and AFLW and be financially robust and continue to grow. It's got to be a safe place. We want to be safe, culturally safe and also safe from a physical point of view. We will continue to put the health and safety of all our players and participants at the forefront."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'There's no boy's club here'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Andrew Dillon: "You only have to look at the calibre of our executive team and the calibre of my football integrity and legal team to say there's no boys club here. "We've got a talented diverse workforce and everyone's opinions are listened to and acted on. The more diverse the talent, the better decisions. I don't buy that one bit."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Will the grand final stay a day game?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Andrew Dillon stays on the fence. "I went to my first grand final in 1976. I've been to two drawn grand finals, I've been to a grand final at Waverly, and was fortunate enough over the last three years to go to a grand final that was at the Gabba at night. "I went to one at Optus Stadium, a twilight grand final and last year was back at the MCG for a day grand final. They've all been amazing. I haven't been to a bad grand final, but last year's was really good."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Why did this process take so long?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Richard Goyder responds: "The most important thing is the outcome of the outcome we announced today. It was towards the end of last year, we wanted to deal with the Hawthorn issue and as we've announced over the weekend, what governments have announced. "Hopefully we can move things forward over the next couple of days, a couple of things that have been the priority of the AFL which are incredibly important to the game so I don't think we've lost any I don't think we've lost any momentum over the period."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'Excitement, relief and trepidation': Dillon on hearing the news
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "It was a mixture of everything. It was excitement, relief and there was trepidation as well. "It's a massive job and a massive responsibility stop but to have Richard and the commission and trust me with that responsibility means a lot. "It was a mixture of everything, but right now I'm really excited. I'm just humbled proud to be here and have this great responsibility."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Dillon's extensive footy background
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "I have been so fortunate to be involved in footy at so many levels throughout my life from my first game as a five year old, right through the junior club and school football. "I umpired, albeit not very well, during my high school years and I played community football for 16 years at a senior level. "I am running an AusKick centre, assistant coach at senior level and coached junior girls' football for five years. I can tell you in my 23 years at the AFL there is been no tougher job than trying to run a training session on a Friday afternoon and under 13 girls team."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'A humbling moment': Dillon
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The new boss is speaking now. "It is a really humbling moment for me to be appointed as the next CEO of the AFL. "Football has been a defining part of my life. As it has for so many of our supporters, it is a privilege and honour to be given the opportunity to leave the AFL. I'm looking forward to working with the AFL team, our clubs, our players, our coaches and the wider industry to ensure our game continues to expand its reach."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Andrew Dillon will take over on October 2
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Richard Goyder confirms the new man's start date. "Andrew will immediately become CEO-elect and in accordance with good practice, and the need for a smooth transition. Gillon McLachlan has agreed to be CEO of AFL until the conclusion of the 2023 AFL premiership season."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Andrew Dillon is here
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: He is joined by AFL chairman Richard Goyder, who says Dillon was the "standout choice" among a competitive field. "He knows the football community, he knows our supporters, volunteers, participants, players and has a clear vision when he wants to take the game to more and more people."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Andrew Dillon is the AFL's new chief executive
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Good morning. The AFL has this morning confirmed that Andrew Dillon will replace Gillon McLachlan as its chief executive. Dillon will front the media shortly, and updates will be live here.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Andrew Dillon named AFL chief executive almost a year after Gillon McLachlan's resignation

image.altText: Aerial view of a housing estate near Camden, NSW

items.synopsis: CoreLogic data shows Australian property prices have risen for the second consecutive month, suggesting a downturn in the housing market is coming to an end as interest rates stabilise.

title.children: House prices rise for second-straight month as interest rates appear to stabilise

image.altText: a smoking ceremony

items.synopsis: The former Wynnum Hospital site has been handed over to a local Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander group, beginning the process of its conversion into a dedicatedÂ Indigenous health and aged care facility.

title.children: Plans for aged care facility tailored to Indigenous residents at site of old hospital

image.altText: An African lady smiling in her new social housing residence

items.synopsis: The Parliamentary Budget OfficeÂ warns phasing out property tax breaksÂ may "trigger a significant economic shock". That's why next week's budget is more focused on increasing the supply of housing rather than trying to make housing affordable by reducing house prices.

title.children: Phasing out property tax breaks could save $74b but it also could create 'significant economic shock'

image.altText: a little boy in a cowboy hat leans on a fence watching a bullriding competition

items.synopsis: The small town of Hughenden âÂ with itsÂ population of just over 1,000 residents âÂ welcomes visitors from across the country seeking stunning views and outback hospitality.

title.children: Tiny town's population doubles with celebration of outback Queensland's vast horizons

image.altText: Woman in singlet top.

items.synopsis: The mother ofÂ Central Coast womanÂ Leisl Smith who vanished in 2012 calls for laws to be amended to allow a verdict for the man who stood trial for her murder â but died â to be released.

title.children: Grieving mum pleads for trial verdict of daughter's murder accused to be unsealed

image.altText: A composite images of Filipina woman Nanette Ambrose with a US flag, and Hilary Clinton with Nanette Ambrose.

items.synopsis: Her workÂ for the USÂ government helped bring down a sex-trafficking syndicate and international fraudsters.Â But Nanette Ambrose gave it all up forÂ the red dirt of Mount Isa â and love.

title.children: Why this undercover agent traded sleuthing for life in the Australian outback

image.altText: A worker smooths concrete at slab pour at building construction site at Radar Street at Lytton at Brisbane.

items.synopsis: Hundreds of infrastructure projects promised by the former federal government are not properly fundedÂ and may be cancelled if a major reviewÂ deems they cannot be delivered.

title.children: Hundreds of 'completely underfunded' Coalition-era infrastructure projects on the chopping block

image.altText: A view from a headland of a beach

items.synopsis: Two men attemptÂ to rescue a woman and a young girl at Coolangatta before also becoming trapped in the surf.Â

title.children: Woman dies after multiple people rescued from big waves at Gold Coast beach

image.altText: a man walking next to an election poster of himself

items.synopsis: The Sydney MP makes formal complaints to police andÂ the NSW anti-discrimination board and says he will launch defamation proceedings unless Mr Latham apologises.

title.children: Alex Greenwich takes legal action against Mark Latham over 'homophobic' tweet

image.altText: ISIS fighters raise their weapons as they stand on a vehicle at an undisclosed location.

items.synopsis: TheÂ leader of the Islamic State group, Abu Hussein al-Qurashi, has been killed in Syria in an operation carried out by TÃ¼rkiye's MIT intelligence agency, according to Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

title.children: TÃ¼rkiye says spy agency has killed Islamic State leader

image.altText: Heather Mitchell stands with two drinks in her hand in a room lit by a table lamp

items.synopsis: Actor Heather Mitchell's life has been as dramatic off screen as it has on. And sheâs channelling those experiences into some of the greatest performances of her career.Â

title.children: How Heather Mitchell survived a 'testosterone, cocaine and alcohol-fuelled' workplace

image.altText: An animation of Earth being orbited by hundreds of objects.

items.synopsis: For millenniaÂ humans have gazed up at the wonder of the night sky, but what we can see is rapidly changing because of our quest to be connected.

title.children: Earth's orbit is becoming more crowded and our window to the universe is at stake

image.altText: Colourful helium balloons with streamers attached floating under a ceiling

items.synopsis: Since 2010, a by-product from a Darwin LNG plant has been Australia's only helium source. But with the feedstock for the gas plant due to run out in the coming months,Â we're about to begin importing it all.

title.children: Helium production in Australia is about to end. Could another source fill the gap?

image.altText: A woman and man walk past the Reserve Bank of Australia's headquarters in Sydney.

items.synopsis: It's now entirely possible the Reserve Bank won't get inflation down to 2-3 per cent, regardless of whether it raises interest rates again. And it's extraordinary this scenario is not being more widely discussed, writes David Taylor.

title.children: Australia may be enduring 'sticky inflation' and interest rate rises are unlikely to solve the underlying problem

image.altText: A man stands against the window

items.synopsis: After a stroke in 2021,Â Richard CrookesÂ travels to Adelaide every eight weeks for rehabilitation because he canât get the treatment he needs in the Northern Territory.

title.children: Richard used to wrangle crocodiles in the Top End. Now he struggles to make a cup of tea

image.altText: House bound for outback Queensland on the back of a truck

items.synopsis: As building a new home becomes more challenging and expensive in regional Queensland, many people are opting to have ready-built houses trucked in from thousands of kilometres away.

title.children: 'Home delivery' booming in outback towns as constructionÂ costs skyrocket

image.altText: Blue, red and white motel sign that reads 'Katanning Jumbuck Motel'.

items.synopsis: One of Australia's largest sheep meat processors has bought an entire motel as they grow desperate to house abattoir workersÂ amid an oversupply of sheep.

title.children: Abattoir buys motel to house more workers with no rentals available in town

image.altText: An apartment block with large blackened area from fire caused by a missile attack and a crane hovering above

items.synopsis: Driving around Ukraine for the past two weeks revealed to me the extent of devastation that Vladimir Putin's war has wrought upon this country so rich in history, culture and potential, writes John Lyons in Kyiv.

title.children: Putin won't give up on Ukraine, but its people are filled with a deep, burning anger and won't surrender

image.altText: a man in glasses sitting in front of a bookshelf

items.synopsis: The scrapping of the interest rate floor five years ago has led to "bad outcomes" for many Australians who secured ultra-cheap home loans during the pandemic and are now facing a fall over the mortgage cliff, says a former head of credit risk at the nation's financial regulator.Â

title.children: The lending boom is biting back against millions of Australians. Glenn's rules were meant to safeguard us

image.altText: The ASX close to steady in early trade as seen on the exchange's board at its Sydney office

items.synopsis: Australia's share market gained last weekÂ and awaits a key rates decisionÂ on Tuesday. Follow theÂ day's events with our blog.

title.children: ASX set to rise after positive week

schema.headline: Live updates: ASX starts again after lifting last week, global stock markets move

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Federal Budget in a week
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Look, the most important day is always today. But with the RBA meeting tomorrow and the Federal Budget next week, let's look ahead a bit. The biggest bank in the nation, the Commonwealth Bank, has put out its preview of next Tuesday's budget and it spells out some assumptions that will help you frame the size of the challenge facing the nation. Here's what the bank says the government is trying to do, at the same time: maintaining fiscal discipline to assist monetary policy in bringing inflation back to the 2%-3% target range providing some targeted relief to cost-of-living pressures putting in place new arrangements to reverse the projected blowout in spending on a number of large programs (ie. NDIS, Aged care) implementing the AUKUS defence policy priorities further developing climate change policies implementing some tax reform and moving the medium-term budget outlook onto a more sustainable footing And don't forget â win the next election so you can start working on the really hard stuff! That said, there's some good news for Treasurer Jim Chalmers. There was a budget last year â in October 2022 â to enact a lot of election promises. The 2022/23 budget deficit is expected to come in well below the estimate that was made then. Data to March shows the 2022/23 deficit running at $A11.2 billion "a substantial $A23.3 billion lower than expectations". If you roll it over 12 months like in this chart, the budget is back to a (very) small surplus â mainly thanks to the strong labour market and company profits.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX 200 opens up 0.65%
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The index of Australia's 200 biggest listed companies has opened up in the first day of trading for the week. The ASX 200 is up 0.62% or 45.3 points to 7,354.30 points.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Here's where we're sitting at 8:30am AEDT
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ASX SPI 200 futures: +0.7% to 7,372 Aussie dollar: 66.09 US cents On Wall Street: Dow +0.8%, S & P 500 =).8%, NASDAQ 0.7% In Europe: FTSE 100 +0.5%, Stoxx 50 stable, IBEX 35 (Madrid) -0.8% Spot gold: $1989.89 USD Iron ore: $103.61 USD Bitcoin: $44,524.96 AUD

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Good morning sunshine
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It's Daniel Ziffer from the ABC business news team with you. I'll be keeping you up to date with the markets and business news all day. Tomorrow, the board of the Reserve Bank of Australia meets to decide the direction of monetary policy - essentially if interest rates will go up, pause (most likely) or go down (very unlikely). But there's plenty on before that. The ASX 200 futures market - where traders essentially bet on where the index will go today - is up 0.7% or 54 points, probably off the back of indicies in the US and UK lifting in last trade. Anyway, new month, big day, let's get started...

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Live updates: ASX starts again after lifting last week, global stock markets move

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Look, the most important day is always today. But with the RBA meeting tomorrow and the Federal Budget next week, let's look ahead a bit. The biggest bank in the nation, the Commonwealth Bank, has put out its preview of next Tuesday's budget and it spells out some assumptions that will help you frame the size of the challenge facing the nation. Here's what the bank says the government is trying to do, at the same time: maintaining fiscal discipline to assist monetary policy in bringing inflation back to the 2%-3% target range providing some targeted relief to cost-of-living pressures putting in place new arrangements to reverse the projected blowout in spending on a number of large programs (ie. NDIS, Aged care) implementing the AUKUS defence policy priorities further developing climate change policies implementing some tax reform and moving the medium-term budget outlook onto a more sustainable footing And don't forget â win the next election so you can start working on the really hard stuff! That said, there's some good news for Treasurer Jim Chalmers. There was a budget last year â in October 2022 â to enact a lot of election promises. The 2022/23 budget deficit is expected to come in well below the estimate that was made then. Data to March shows the 2022/23 deficit running at $A11.2 billion "a substantial $A23.3 billion lower than expectations". If you roll it over 12 months like in this chart, the budget is back to a (very) small surplus â mainly thanks to the strong labour market and company profits.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal Budget in a week

children.content: Look, the most important day is always
today
But with the RBA meeting tomorrow and the Federal Budget next week, let's look ahead a bit.

The biggest bank in the nation, the Commonwealth Bank, has put out its preview of next Tuesday's budget and it spells out some assumptions that will help you frame the size of the challenge facing the nation.
Here's what the bank says the government is trying to do, at the same time:
maintaining fiscal discipline to assist monetary policy in bringing inflation back to the 2%-3% target range
providing some targeted relief to cost-of-living pressures
putting in place new arrangements to reverse the projected blowout in spending on a number of large programs (ie. NDIS, Aged care)
implementing the AUKUS defence policy priorities
further developing climate change policies
implementing some tax reform and moving the medium-term budget outlook onto a more sustainable footing
And don't forget â win the next election so you can start working on the really hard stuff!
That said, there's some good news for Treasurer Jim Chalmers.
There was a budget last year â in October 2022 â to enact a lot of election promises. The 2022/23 budget deficit is expected to come in well below the estimate that was made then.

Data to March shows the 2022/23 deficit running at $A11.2 billion "a substantial $A23.3 billion lower than expectations". If you roll it over 12 months like in this chart, the budget is back to a (very) small surplus â mainly thanks to the strong labour market and company profits.
underlying budget balance
(Dept of Finance)

The ASX 200 futures market - where traders essentially bet on where the index will go today - is up 0.7% or 54 points, probably off the back of indicies in the US and UK lifting in last trade.
Anyway, new month, big day, let's get started...
